content:
Exemption for certain state and local political committees from notification and reporting requirements under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Political committees of state or local candidates and state or local committees of political parties are exempt from notifying the Secretary and reporting requirements. The amendments take effect as if included in Public Law 106-230. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include qualified State or local political organizations as exempt from certain requirements. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include qualified State or local political organizations as exempt from certain requirements. A qualified State or local political organization is defined as a political organization that focuses on influencing the selection of individuals for State or local public offices and complies with state reporting laws. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include qualified State or local political organizations as exempt from certain requirements. This includes providing information on expenditures, contributions, and the individuals involved. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to exempt qualified State or local political organizations from certain reporting requirements. This includes making reports public and available for inspection, disregarding certain state law differences in reporting thresholds. The amendment exempts qualified State or local political organizations from certain reporting requirements, including differences in reporting thresholds under State law. The minimum amount required to be reported under State law cannot exceed $300 more than the minimum amount required under subsection (j), and the organization is not required to identify certain information. The organization must report details such as the employer and occupation of contributors, recipients of expenditures, purpose of expenditures, and dates of contributions and expenditures. The organization must report specific details about contributors and expenditures. A qualified State or local political organization will not lose its status due to minor errors in compliance as long as they are promptly corrected. Federal candidates or office holders cannot control or significantly influence such organizations to be considered qualified. The organization's definition excludes candidates or office holders who control or participate in its direction, solicit contributions, or direct disbursements. The effective date for these amendments is retroactive to Public Law 106-230. SEC. 3. EXEMPTION FROM ANNUAL RETURN REQUIREMENTS. Income Tax Returns Required Only for Political Organization. Taxable Income paragraph of section 6012(a) of the Internal Revenue Code amended. Income Tax Returns Not Subject to Disclosure. Amendments made to subsections of section 6104 regarding disclosure and public inspection of annual returns. Amendments made to public inspection and information returns requirements for political organizations under the Internal Revenue Code. Public inspection rules updated for certain annual returns, and information returns required by political organizations revised. The section applies to political organizations with gross receipts of $25,000 or more, or $100,000 for qualified State or local political organizations. They must file an annual return with necessary information for IRS purposes. The section applies to political organizations with gross receipts of $25,000 or more, requiring them to file an annual return with necessary information for IRS purposes. Organizations exempt from taxation under section 501(a) must provide specific information for carrying out section 527, with additional details as deemed necessary by the Secretary. Mandatory exceptions from filing apply to certain types of organizations. Certain types of organizations are exempt from filing under certain conditions, including State or local political committees, caucuses or associations of officials, candidate committees, national party committees, and House or Senate campaign committees. These exemptions are outlined in the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971. Certain organizations, such as political party committees, House or Senate campaign committees, and those required to report under the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971, may be exempt from filing information returns under certain conditions. The Secretary has the discretion to relieve organizations from filing if it's deemed unnecessary for efficient tax administration. The Secretary has the discretion to exempt organizations from filing information returns if it is deemed unnecessary for efficient tax administration. The amendments made by this section will take effect retroactively. The Secretary of the Treasury, in consultation with the Federal Election Commission, will publicize the effect of the amendments made by the Act and the interaction of reporting requirements under section 527 of the Internal Revenue Code and the Federal Election Campaign Act. Information provided will be included in guidance issued to the public. Additionally, there is a provision for waiver of filing amounts. SEC. 5. WAIVER OF FILING AMOUNTS. The Secretary may waive taxes or amounts imposed on organizations for failure to comply with requirements if due to reasonable cause. Effective after June 30, 2000.

SEC. 6. MODIFICATIONS TO SECTION 527 ORGANIZATION DISCLOSURE PROVISIONS. (a) Unsegregated Funds Not To Avoid Tax.--Paragraph (4) of section 527(i) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include exempt function income as any amount described in subsection (c)(3), whether segregated or not. (b) Procedures for Assessment and Collection of Amounts.--Paragraph (1) of section 527(j) is amended to state that the amount imposed shall be assessed and collected like penalties under section 6652(c). (c) Duplicate Written Filings Not Required.--Subparagraph (A) of section 527(i)(1) is amended. For purposes of subtitle F, the amount imposed by this paragraph shall be assessed and collected in the same manner as penalties imposed by section 6652(c). Section 527(i)(1) is amended by removing duplicate written filings. Section 7207 is amended to apply the fraud penalty to returns filed under specific sections. Section 527(j)(3) is amended regarding the contents of reports. Section 527(j)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include additional details in the contents of reports and electronic filing requirements for organizations with contributions or expenditures exceeding $50,000 in a calendar year. The amendment requires organizations with contributions or expenditures over $50,000 in a calendar year to file reports electronically and make them publicly available online within 48 hours. The Secretary must make notices and reports available to the public online within 48 hours of filing. The database must be searchable by organization names, states, zip codes, custodians of records, directors, purposes, related entities, and contributors. The database of notices and reports must be searchable by organization names, states, zip codes, custodians of records, directors, purposes, related entities, contributors, employers of contributors, recipients of expenditures, ranges of contributions and expenditures, and time periods. It should also be downloadable. The database of notices and reports must be searchable by various criteria and downloadable. Amendments are made to the Internal Revenue Code regarding the contents and timing of notices in case of material changes. Amendments to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 require timely notification of material changes, with a deadline of 30 days after the change. Failure to comply with this requirement will result in consequences outlined in the code. Amendments to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 require timely notification of material changes, with a deadline of 30 days after the change. Failure to comply will result in consequences outlined in the code. The amendments specify that income and deductions should only be considered during the period from the date of the material change to the date of notice. Effective dates for the amendments vary depending on the subsection, with some applying to failures occurring after the enactment of the Act and others retroactively. The amendments made by subsections (a) and (b) apply to failures after the enactment of the Act, while subsection (c) takes effect retroactively. Subsection (d) applies to reports filed after the enactment date, and subsections (e)(1) and (f) apply to reports filed more than 30 days after the enactment. Subsections (e)(2) and (e)(3) apply to reports filed after June 30, 2003. Subsection (g) contains general amendments. The amendments made by subsection (g) of the Act apply to material changes on or after the enactment date. A transition rule is provided for material changes within 30 days of enactment, allowing for a delayed filing of a notice under section 527(i) of the Internal Revenue Code. Notices, reports, or returns filed with the Secretary of the Treasury before the enactment of the amendments will continue to be subject to disclosure provisions under section 6104 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986.
